title: A block launched off a table to find g lab

Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown, which includes a block of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that sits on the surface of a table that can be considered frictionless. The block is pressed against a spring of known spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and then compressed a distance <math alttext="l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is then launched off the table which has a height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols you defined in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) In another experiment, the block is pushed against the spring and released. Instead of launching off the table it collides and sticks to a long uniform rod pivoted around the end as shown above. Which of the following quantities, if any, are not constant during the collision?

• Kinetic Energy

• Linear Momentum

• Angular Momentum
